climbs.name: A Woman's Work is Never Done

content.description:
This route starts on the west face of Labor Dome, just left of center. The route climbs a short left-facing crack/corner to reach a small roof, where it traverses right (still easy) to reach a thinning crack that climbs upward and curves slightly right at the top. Climb that crack, placing gear while you can. Put your small pieces up as high and as possible and then crank the crux sequence (a tiny cam might be as high as your waist). It's good to have a few pieces, since small cams are known to pull from desert granite. Finish on the easier slab and belay in a rounded ledge below the roof.

To descend, walk/scramble to climber's right (south) as described in the "rock" page.
content.protection: A set of nuts and cams from hand-sized to as small as possible (the smaller they are, the closer they will be when you pull the crux.)

content.description: This is a very clean steep finger crack.  It is very short, with only one hard move.
content.location: The first crack to the left of A Woman's Work Is Never Done.

content.description:
Start with the arete/face just left of the start of A Woman's Work is Never Done, then climb a contrived line up the face between the cracks of A Woman's Work is Never Done and the upper part of CornFlakes/Blue Collar.

Good moves on good rock.
content.protection: Some large CDs. (4-inch) and a bit of extension is useful to rig a TR anchor.

climbs.name: Toil & Trouble
climbs.fa: Todd & Donette Swain, Maria Pajerska & Todd Van der Star 12-2014

content.description:
Start about 30 feet left of

Working Overtime

by a pine tree. Climb up flakes to gain a sloping ledge below an obvious left facing corner. Climb the corner to the top.
content.protection: Carry a standard JT rack. Cams and cord needed to build an anchor for TR.
content.location:
Start about 30 feet left of

Working Overtime

by a pine tree.

climbs.name: Time and A Half
climbs.fa: (TR) Randy Leavitt 1986, FL: Tony Walker, December 1990

content.description: To the right of  "Woman's Work Is Never Done", climb up into an alcove with a roof. Move out over the roof and follow a thin crack to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5", mainly thin. Usually top roped.

climbs.name: Swing Shift
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, March 2009.

content.description: Begin about 30 feet right of Time and a Half, around the right side of the arete. Climb up to a horizontal crack, traverse left onto the face left of the arete, then climb the thin crack on the low-angle slab past a bush to the top.
content.protection: Double rack of CDs .3 to .5 inches, then 1-each from .75 to 3-inches

climbs.name: Scabs
climbs.fa: Dave Haber and Sheryl Haber, April 1993

content.description: Begin just left of A Woman's Work is Never Done and climb a short dihedral to a small roof. Over this to join the cracks of Corn Flakes.
content.location: This is essentially a poorly protected direct start to what is now called Corn Flakes, but was actually climbed first.

content.description:
This route starts on the West Face of the Labor-dome, left of center, on the horizontals just left of the start of Woman's Work. The route climbs a small and short left-facing crack/corner to reach a small roof, where it traverses LEFT under the roof (crux) and out around the left-hand edge of a horizontal flake, then over it, moving right to get on top of the flake.  Run it out a bit on the easier slab and belay in a rounded ledge below the roof.

On the 12/26 ascent, John D. was "running" up this (following) near dusk faster than I could suck in rope. 3 feet from the top he snapped off a hold and fell about 10-12 feet down the face (no injury). There may be more "temporary" holds nearby on this line, so please beware. It seems possible that this lead was a FFA. It was an undocumented line at the time according to the book.

To descend, walk/scramble to climber's right (south) as described in the "rock" page.
content.protection: A set of nuts and set of cams from .5" to 3"

content.description:
Start in the same spot as

Working Overtime

. Climb the large, left facing corner just left of

Working Overtime

to a ceiling about 30 feet up. Step up and left around the ceiling on small horizontals until you encounter a smooth, varnished face (this face is about 6-8 feet left of the upper layback flake of

Working Overtime

). Make a few thin moves up the varnished face to the top.
content.protection: Large cams and some anchor material make a good TR anchor.
content.location:
Start in the same spot as

Working Overtime

, below a large, left facing corner with a grass clump about 10 feet up.

climbs.name: Corn Flakes
climbs.fa: Kim Heidel and Nicole Toner, January, 2000.

content.description: Same start as Women's Work is Never Done, but after about 15 feet move left on a horizontal crack, traversing up and left to join Blue Collar/Scabs.

Left-leaning splitter with abundant jugs on the short upper tier.  Probably done before.  Giving it a non-generic name for the time being, instead of adding yet another Unknown to the world.  If someone knows its original name and FA info, happy to update to reflect.
content.protection: Light rack of cams to 2", gear anchor.  Walk off as for Working Overtime and A Woman's Work Is Never Done.
content.location: Middle of the north-facing upper short wall about 20 ft away from the topouts of Toil & Trouble and Labor O' Love.

content.description: Starting on a block below just below the arete.  Step up on face using arete to gain a left facing flake with hand jams and larger gear, route trends up and right up obvious crack to summit.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5" - 1.25" to 2.5" for anchor.  No bolted anchor, walk off to the north/east down boulders.
content.location: Left arete between Working Overtime & A Woman's Work is never done.
